channel.title: So... you think you're a hacker

item.title: So... you think you're a hacker
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:32, topic:449036”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=551935.msg4044787#msg4044787 date=1342004719]

[quote author=t4 link=topic=551935.msg4044558#msg4044558 date=1341972713]

or are you all just bandwagoning because someone said VB is shit

It’s from CSI Miami. A guy says he’s been tracking some dude for a while now, and this woman says “I’ll create a GUI interface in Visual Basic, see if I can get an IP address”.
[/quote]by bandwagoning i’m talking about people saying VB is shit prior to this thread, it seems to be the general consensus here that it is shit and i’m wondering if anyone can explain why because evidently some people are only taking it as a joke due to that clip.

edit: specifically in this thread i’m talking about t4’s comment, albeit i’m not sure if it was mocking the GUI creation difficulty of java or the suggestion of it being a viable language. either way, someone tell me why VB is so bad!

it was more on the accused difficulty of UI design in swing.

in regards to VB being bad: VB programmers do not focus on useful programming paradigms, instead they rely on wizards and bloated tools. the development process turns in to a mindless copy/paste and doesn’t focus on the underlying implementations. VB is also a simple language (not that there’s anything wrong with that), but it’s meant for elementary programmers… ie, what a grade school would push. based on the aforementioned, i would say VB is only a shit language because of its userbase and its values.
[/quote]if we’re going to take userbase into account then i would say Lisp is partly a shit language too because a fair portion of the people that use it are extremely rude (comp.lang.lisp). i would also say that Java is in part a shit language because it’s also often used by beginners to write atrocious code, as is Python etc. this is why i don’t particularly regard the argument of userbase, every language’s userbase has good and bad people and programmers.

values are a little bit more of an argument i care about, but even then, it falls into more of a meta category because it’s not actually a technical problem rather than just unattractiveness in how the language has been pushed by the creators. fundamentally, these arguments are actually quite poor against the language itself and turn the cannons towards Microsoft instead with how they’ve handled VB’s growth and advertisement. in the discernment between VB.NET and VB6, VB.NET was such a step up from VB6 (which was borked in several well noted ways) that i’d regard it on-par with C# for the most part, it just seems like people are too historically against VB because of VB6 and bandwagon against it because they lack the capacity to judge it adequately themselves.

i think you’re missing something in regards to the userbase, and that is that Java and C# are use in a professional environment. I’ve never meant ANYONE that would put that they have experience in VB on their resume or get hired to write applications in VB.[/quote]VB.NET is used in many professional environments and i’m very sure there are many people that would put their experience with it on their resume and actively seek jobs with it, you’re generalising according to your own narrow experiences. remember that not every company or developer thinks it’s a joke, they see it for the tool that it actually is and their good experiences with it so far won’t make them liable to changing anytime soon.

Read full topic
item.source: So... you think you're a hacker

VB is also a simple language (not that there’s anything wrong with that), but it’s meant for elementary programmers… ie, what a grade school would push. based on the aforementioned, i would say VB is only a shit language because of its userbase and its values.
[/quote]if we’re going to take userbase into account then i would say Lisp is partly a shit language too because a fair portion of the people that use it are extremely rude (comp.lang.lisp). i would also say that Java is in part a shit language because it’s also often used by beginners to write atrocious code, as is Python etc. this is why i don’t particularly regard the argument of userbase, every language’s userbase has good and bad people and programmers.

values are a little bit more of an argument i care about, but even then, it falls into more of a meta category because it’s not actually a technical problem rather than just unattractiveness in how the language has been pushed by the creators. fundamentally, these arguments are actually quite poor against the language itself and turn the cannons towards Microsoft instead with how they’ve handled VB’s growth and advertisement. in the discernment between VB.NET and VB6, VB.NET was such a step up from VB6 (which was borked in several well noted ways) that i’d regard it on-par with C# for the most part, it just seems like people are too historically against VB because of VB6 and bandwagon against it because they lack the capacity to judge it adequately themselves.[/quote]
i think you’re missing something in regards to the userbase, and that is that Java and C# are use in a professional environment. I’ve never meant ANYONE that would put that they have experience in VB on their resume or get hired to write applications in VB.

item.title: So... you think you're a hacker
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

BSD, Lunix, Debian and Mandrake are all versions of an illegal hacker operation system, invented by a Soviet computer hacker named Linyos Torovoltos, before the Russians lost the Cold War. It is based on a program called “xenix”, which was written by Microsoft for the US government. These programs are used by hackers to break into other people’s computer systems to steal credit card numbers. They may also be used to break into people’s stereos to steal their music, using the “mp3” program. Torovoltos is a notorious hacker, responsible for writing many hacker programs, such as “telnet”, which is used by hackers to connect to machines on the internet without using a telephone.

brb virus scan…

Read full topic
